awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Resolution in context: Identity and nonidentity in anaphora resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this dissertation research is to enhance the scientific understanding of sentence production and comprehension by examining the relationship between two types of linguistic construction and the surrounding linguistic and nonlinguistic context. Linguists have long been aware that speakers' awareness of what information is available in the broad context of utterance affects how they use and interpret language, but the exact effects of this knowledge on certain parts of the linguistic system have not been fully identified. The constructions under investigation in this dissertation are verb phrase ellipsis, in which a silent "gap" after an auxiliary verb is interpreted as containing full verbal content, and deaccenting, in which the pronunciation of a sentential constituent is de-emphasized to indicate that it is redundant. Previous analyses have suggested that both phenomena are licit only when they can be construed as identical to an overt antecedent that appears earlier in the linguistic discourse. This dissertation investigates evidence that previous formulations of identity for these phenomena have been too strict, and that they can be licensed and interpreted with respect to a broader range of linguistic antecedents, as well as with respect to information available in the nonlinguistic context. In addition to advancing the scientific understanding of these phenomena, this research may have technological and clinical applications. A more complete understanding of how listeners integrate linguistic and nonlinguistic information to interpret these constructions may lead to the development of artificial language systems that produce and interpret language more similarly to human speakers, as well as diagnosis and treatment strategies for speakers whose use of these constructions is impaired.
 
The dissertation project focuses on three main research questions: (1) Is salient information from the nonlinguistic context considered during the interpretation of verb phrase ellipsis when there is a linguistic antecedent that could provide a reasonable interpretation? (2) Can deaccenting of a particular constituent be licensed by linguistic relations other than repetition, i.e., entailment, bridging, or world knowledge inferences? (3) Can deaccenting be licensed, in whole or in part, by information made salient in the nonlinguistic context? The two phenomena will be investigated using production, perception, and eye-tracking methodologies that examine the use and interpretation of verb phrase ellipsis and deaccenting both offline and in real time. The results will enhance models of how these constructions are licensed and interpreted in a more comprehensive discourse context than has previously been considered, by taking into account linguistically evoked information, inferrable information, and salient nonlinguistic information.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated two context-sensitive linguistic constructions. In verb phrase ellipsis (VPE), a verb phrase appears to be "missing" after an auxiliary verb, but the sentence is interpreted as if it is present ("John will go to the store tomorrow, and Mary will      too."). In anaphoric deaccenting, a notionally "given" word or phrase receives a reduced pronunciation ("He asked if I wanted coffee, and I replied that I hate coffee."). Prior literature has debated the relative contributions of local linguistic antecedents versus the discourse context at large in determining when speakers find these constructions acceptable to use, and how listeners interpret them when they hear them. We sought to experimentally determine whether the linguistic antecedent or the broad discourse context is more privileged in determining when these constructions sound good and how they are interpreted.

In our investigation of verb phrase ellipsis, we focused on assessing how listeners interpret VPE constructions in situations where the linguistic antecedent and the broader discourse context provide competing information suggesting different interpretations for the sentence. Our results consistently showed that listeners' interpretation preferences did not reliably conform to the predictions of either the antecedent-driven or the context-driven models of ellipsis interpretation; rather, at the group level, listeners seemed to employ a strategy that could be described as combining the two approaches. We followed up by constructing and comparing several probabilistic models of VPE interpretation, and the result supported a "hybrid" account where interpretation was driven by the discourse at large, but constrained by the form of the linguistic antecedent beyond the direct contribution it makes to the discourse.

In our exploration of anaphoric deaccenting, we focused on whether people produced certain verbs with an emphasized or de-emphasized pronunciation, as well as how good listeners thought emphasized and de-emphasized verbs sounded, in contexts where they were preceded by an identical verb, a different verb that entailed the meaning of the target verb, or a different verb that strongly implied the meaning of the target verb. Contrary to the predominant accounts in the linguistic literature, we found that speakers tend to produce de-emphasized verbs, and listeners to rate de-emphasized verbs as sounding good, only when they were preceded by an identical verb, and not by a verb that entailed or implied their meaning. However, this tendency can be reversed if the discourse context is carefully constructed to highlight the fact that a prior non-identical verb makes the meaning of the target verb salient.

Within theoretical linguistics, this work has made an important empircal contribution that points to the shortcomings of some of the prior models of the licensing and interpretation of VPE and anaphoric deaccenting as a means of explaining naturalistic human communication. In our work, we highlight some important changes to prior theories that will allow them to better account for our data, and we expect that future theoretical work will further improve the fit between theoretical models and the experimental data we gathered.

Outside of theoretical linguistics, our work serves as an interesting case study of the complex interface between the linguistic system, which is generally thought to consist of highly structured, domain-specific representations of form and meaning, and mental representations of our surroundings, which may implicate more general cognitive processes such as sensory perception and memory. It may inform other work in this vein and shed light on how humans navigate the interface between these two systems.

Our research also provides important new characterization of linguistic constructions that have received relatively little rigorous description. Our experimental results, and future work in the same vein, may provide useful reference points for the diagnosis of language disorders that impair the use or comprehension of linguistic constructions that depend critically on a linguistic antecedent or interface with the discourse context in complex ways. They may also contribute to the construction of artificial language systems that can produce and comprehend language in increasingly human-like ways.
